font-weight:Normal; font-size: 12px; text-anchor: middle; font-family: arial,helvetica; fill: #333333;
font-weight:Normal; font-size: 12px; text-anchor: middle; font-family: arial,helvetica; fill: #333333;
font-weight:Normal; font-size: 12px; text-anchor: start; font-family: arial,helvetica; fill: #333333;
font-weight:Normal; font-size: 12px; text-anchor: middle; font-family: arial,helvetica; fill: #333333;
font-weight:Normal; font-size: 12px; text-anchor: start; font-family: arial,helvetica; fill: #666666;
text.tspan: We consider origin/develop to be the main branch where the source code of
HEAD always reflects a state with the latest delivered development changes for
When the source code in the develop branch reaches a stable point and is ready
to be released, all of the changes should be merged back into master somehow
and then tagged with a release number.

text.style: font-weight:Normal; font-size: 12px; text-anchor: middle; font-family: arial,helvetica; fill: #333333;
font-weight:Normal; font-size: 12px; text-anchor: start; font-family: arial,helvetica; fill: #333333;
font-weight:Normal; font-size: 12px; text-anchor: middle; font-family: arial,helvetica; fill: #333333;
font-weight:Normal; font-size: 12px; text-anchor: start; font-family: arial,helvetica; fill: #666666;
text.tspan: We consider origin/master to be the main branch where the source code of HEAD
Therefore, each time when changes are merged back into master, this is a new
production release by definition. We tend to be very strict at this, so that
theoretically, we could use a Git hook script to automatically build and roll-out our
software to our production servers everytime there was a commit on master.

text.style: font-weight:Normal; font-size: 12px; text-anchor: middle; font-family: arial,helvetica; fill: #333333;
font-weight:Normal; font-size: 12px; text-anchor: start; font-family: arial,helvetica; fill: #333333;
font-weight:Normal; font-size: 12px; text-anchor: middle; font-family: arial,helvetica; fill: #333333;
font-weight:Normal; font-size: 12px; text-anchor: middle; font-family: arial,helvetica; fill: #333333;
font-weight:Normal; font-size: 12px; text-anchor: start; font-family: arial,helvetica; fill: #333333;
font-weight:Normal; font-size: 12px; text-anchor: middle; font-family: arial,helvetica; fill: #333333;
font-weight:Normal; font-size: 12px; text-anchor: start; font-family: arial,helvetica; fill: #666666;
text.tspan: Release branches support preparation of a new production release. They allow for
last-minute dotting of i’s and crossing t’s. Furthermore, they allow for minor bug fixes.
The key moment to make a new release branch is when develop (almost) reflects the
desired state of the new release. It is exactly at the start of a release branch that the
upcoming release gets assigned a version number.

text.style: font-weight:Normal; font-size: 12px; text-anchor: middle; font-family: arial,helvetica; fill: #333333;
font-weight:Normal; font-size: 12px; text-anchor: start; font-family: arial,helvetica; fill: #333333;
font-weight:Normal; font-size: 12px; text-anchor: middle; font-family: arial,helvetica; fill: #333333;
font-weight:Normal; font-size: 12px; text-anchor: start; font-family: arial,helvetica; fill: #666666;
text.tspan: Hotfix branches arise from the necessity to act immediately upon an undesired
state of a live production version. When a critical bug in a production version must
be resolved immediately, a hotfix branch may be branched off from the
corresponding tag on the master branch that marks the production version.

text.style: font-weight:Normal; font-size: 12px; text-anchor: middle; font-family: arial,helvetica; fill: #333333;
font-weight:Normal; font-size: 12px; text-anchor: start; font-family: arial,helvetica; fill: #333333;
font-weight:Normal; font-size: 12px; text-anchor: middle; font-family: arial,helvetica; fill: #333333;
font-weight:Normal; font-size: 12px; text-anchor: middle; font-family: arial,helvetica; fill: #333333;
font-weight:Normal; font-size: 12px; text-anchor: start; font-family: arial,helvetica; fill: #333333;
font-weight:Normal; font-size: 12px; text-anchor: middle; font-family: arial,helvetica; fill: #333333;
font-weight:Normal; font-size: 12px; text-anchor: start; font-family: arial,helvetica; fill: #666666;
text.tspan: Branch naming convention: anything except master, develop, release-
Feature branches are used to develop new features for the upcoming or a distant
The essence of a feature branch is that it exists as long as the feature is in
development, but will eventually be merged back into develop (to definitely add the
new feature to the upcoming release) or discarded (in case of a disappointing
Feature branches typically exist in developer repos only, not in origin.

text.style: font-weight:Normal; font-size: 16px; text-anchor: end; font-family: Arial; fill: #ccc;
